sub_topic: Calculating the molar mass of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the molar mass of potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7) in grams per mole?
message_2:
To find the molar mass of potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7), we need to add the molar masses of all the elements in the compound.

Potassium (K) has a molar mass of 39.10 g/mol.
Chromium (Cr) has a molar mass of 51.996 g/mol.
Oxygen (O) has a molar mass of 16.00 g/mol.

In the compound K2Cr2O7, there are:
- 2 potassium atoms
- 2 chromium atoms
- 7 oxygen atoms

So, the molar mass of potassium dichromate is:

(2 × 39.10 g/mol) + (2 × 51.996 g/mol) + (7 × 16.00 g/mol) = 78.20 g/mol + 103.992 g/mol + 112.00 g/mol = 294.192 g/mol

The molar mass of potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7) is approximately 294.19 g/mol.
